nodes.text: High public and external debt levels are systematically related to lower economic growth and, in some contexts, higher inflation

Method: Constructed a multi-country historical dataset on central government debt covering 44 countries and about 200 years with over 3,700 annual observations; supplemented with recent external debt series

Result/Evidence: For advanced economies (20 countries, 1946–2009), median GDP growth when public debt is above 90% of GDP is roughly 1 percentage point lower than at lower debt levels and mean growth almost 4 percentage points lower

Result/Evidence: For emerging markets, public debt above 90% of GDP is associated with median growth falling to about 2.9 percent (from about 4–4.5 percent at below 90%), and average growth falling to about 1 percent

Result/Evidence: For emerging markets, higher public debt levels are associated with substantially higher inflation; median inflation rises from under 7% to about 16% when public debt exceeds 90% of GDP

Result/Evidence: For external gross debt in emerging markets, growth deteriorates markedly when external debt exceeds 60% of GDP and collapses further above 90% of GDP; at 60% external debt annual growth declines by about 2 percentage points, and above 90% growth rates are roughly cut in half or worse
Claim: In advanced economies there is no systematic relationship between high public debt and inflation as a group, despite individual country exceptions

Claim: The empirical patterns of lower growth at very high public debt levels are remarkably similar across advanced and emerging economies for public debt, but only emerging markets show coincident high inflation
Claim: External debt thresholds for adverse outcomes are lower than public debt thresholds in emerging markets, reflecting vulnerability from foreign-currency-denominated obligations

Mechanism/Claim: The nonlinear adverse effect of high debt on growth is consistent with debt intolerance and a nonlinear market interest rate response that forces fiscal adjustment, defaults, or inflationary outcomes under fiscal dominance
Evidence/Result: The 2007–2009 period saw sharp increases in public debt: crisis countries averaged about a 75% rise in real public debt since 2007, while non-crisis countries rose about 20%
Claim: Shortening the maturity structure and reliance on short-term borrowing increases vulnerability to confidence crises and sudden financial crises

Claim/Evidence: Private sector deleveraging typically follows financial crises, reducing private credit, coinciding with higher unemployment and lower growth, and thus can exacerbate the post-crisis slowdown alongside rising public debt

Conclusion: Across the historical sample, public debt/GDP above roughly 90% is associated with notably lower growth; external debt above about 60% (emerging markets) is associated with adverse growth, and countries rarely 'grow' their way out of such high debt burdens
Limitation: Unable to calculate long-run external debt thresholds for advanced countries because comprehensive external debt time series for advanced countries begin only around 2000
